description: Erection of a three bedroom end of terrace dwelling
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: As required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

Prior to above ground works details of all external facing finishes and materials (including specification, colour and texture) to be utilised in the development have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The development shall be built in accordance with these approved details.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to commencement of development on site, a Construction Management Plan (CMP) or Construction Method Statement (CMS) shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The development shall only be implemented in accordance with the approved CMP/CMS and shall be adhered to throughout the entire construction period. The CMP/CMS shall provide for:(a) 	Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) 	Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c)	Temporary site access(d) 	Signing system for works traffic.(e) 	Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(f)	Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g)	Measures to protect any tree, shrubbery and other landscape features to be retained on the site during the course of development.(h)	Means of enclosure of the site.(i) 	Wheel washing equipment.(j) 	The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(k) 	The erection and maintenance of security hoarding including decorative displays and facilities for public viewing, where appropriate.(l)	A scheme for recycling/disposing of waste resulting from demolition and construction works. (m) 	Hours of operation.These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase. Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted details of secure cycle parking facilities for the occupants of, and visitors to, shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.	Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory cycle storage facilities and in the interests of highway safety in accordance with Policy DM8 (Sustainable Transport for New Developments) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted details of the refuse and recycling facilities shall be submitted and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory refuse and recycling facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The car parking arrangement shall be provided on site in accordance with `AR 000 Proposed Plan for the Highway Engineers` and shall be provided with a hard bound dust free surface, adequately drained before the development to which it relates is occupied and thereafter it shall be kept free from obstruction at all times for use by the occupier of the development and shall not thereafter be used for any purpose other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of the development and visitors to it. Reason: In the interests of highway safety, to ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking accommodation and to avoid the congestion of surrounding roads by parked vehicles in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The hard surface hereby approved shall be made of porous materials and retained thereafter or provision shall be made and retained thereafter to direct run-off water from the hard surface to a permeable or porous area or surface within the curtilage of the property. Reason: To reduce the risk of flooding and pollution and increase the level of sustainability of the development and to comply with Policy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no extensions to the proposed dwellinghouse shall be erected within the site curtilages without written consent of the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To safeguard the privacy and amenity of adjoining occupiers and maintain adequate amenity space of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority, within 3 months of first occupation of the development a Post-Construction Review Certificate issued by the Building Research Establishment or other  equivalent assessors confirming that the development has achieved not less than the CO2 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes level 4. Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of evidence required for Post Construction Stage from Ene1 & Wat1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Technical Guide. Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105l/p/ day must be submitted to and approved by the Local Planning Authority, unless otherwise agreed in writing.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (July 2011) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Condition 4 (Fire Safety Strategy) of planning permission 22/03485/FUL states:Notwithstanding the submitted Fire Safety Statement, prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a Fire Safety Strategy shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The Fire Safety Strategy shall demonstrate how the development will achieve the highest standards of fire safety and shall include the following details:1) suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point;2) Appropriate fire alarm systems;3) Passive and active fire safety measures;4) appropriate construction details to minimise the risk of fire spread;5) provision of suitable and convenient means of escape/ an evacuation strategy;6) provision of suitable access and equipment for firefighting which is appropriate for the size and use of the development. The Fire Safety Strategy shall include a statement of competence.The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved Strategy and thereafter maintained.The required Fire Safety Strategy shall reference the London Plan Guidance Fire Safety (February 2022) where applicable and a Reasonable Exception Statement (RES) shall be submitted in relation to those fire safety requirements which the applicant does not consider to be relevant.Reason: In the interests of fire safety and to ensure the safety of all building users in accordance with Policy D12 (Fire safety) of the London Plan 2021.Officer response: The submitted Fire Safety Statement/Reasonable Exception Statement (RES) is considered to be sufficient. As such, the details submitted in relation to Condition 4 (Fire Safety Strategy) are hereby approved. The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved information and thereafter maintained.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above are agreed and that Condition 23 (Travel Plan) of planning permission 20/02216/CREG3 is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2012.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe site comprises a residential dwelling.Consultation No response received AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: It is considered that the proposed roof extension would be an incongruous addition to the host property that would unbalance the pair of semi-detached properties it forms part of which currently have a hipped roof form on both properties. Whilst it is acknowledged that the applicant has cited an example of a similar proposal in the vicinity of the site to the rear on Ashcroft Road it is considered that this does not appear to be the prevailing character and appearance of the roofscapes in this area which are predominantly of a hipped form. The development at Ashcroft Road cited has been carried out under permitted development which does not assess impact on character and appearance and whilst it is acknowledged there may be some form of fall back position in terms of the possibility of a similar development at the application site it is considered that given the context of its surroundings the proposal would create an unwanted precedent and in turn it is considered that the harm caused to the character and appearance of the area as a result of the proposal would outweigh any fall back posiion in this regard. It is considered that the propsal would detract from the character and appearance of the host property and the surrounding area. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to not be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than not in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.

Reasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans/documents submitted for the purposes of this application are consistent with the parent planning permission reference 20/02942/FUL, however, any inconsistencies would be resolved in favour of the parent permission. An Application for Approval of Details Reserved by Condition should not be used to evolve or modify the scheme in a way that is substantially different from that set out in the application.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2012.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe site comprises a residential dwelling.ConsultationOne objection received. The objection can be summarised as follows - Access or traffic problems - Car park issuesAssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- Housing Delivery; - Quality of accommodation;- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings;- Highways; and-any other mattersHousing Delivery The proposal would result in the net increase of one self contained 3 bed unit. The borough does not have a 5 year housing supply and the proposal would assist in the borough meeting its year on year target of 964 new homes over a 10 year period as set by Table 4.1 Policy H1 of the London Plan. Quality of accommodationThe proposed accommodation of the new unit would comply with the internal space standards required by Policy D6 of the London Plan Policy and is of a practical layout. The proposal would provide sufficient outdoor private amenity space for the future occupants of the proposed new unit of accommodation in line with the Council's adopted LDF Resdiential Design Guide. The applicant however has not demonstrated that the reduction in floorspace to the host donor property would not result in the internal floorspace falling below the minimum threshold for a 2 bed dwellinghouse set by Policy D6 of the London Plan. It would appear based on the information submitted that the donor property would be reduced to an internal floorspace below 70sqm and as such would result in the reduction in the standard of accommodation at the donor host property and be substandard to the minimum London Plan Policy D6 required for a 2bed 3p unit.   DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. It is considered that the proposed building would not be a subordinate addition to the host property and the terrace in which it would form part of. The proposed first floor would extend in excess of 3metres beyond the rear building line of the host property and that of the rear building line of the terrace which it forms part of. It would create a dominant and overbearing feature at the rear and would be visually intrusive in the private views of the site from the rear of the neighbouring properties as a result of its its size, height and projection. In addition, due to the gap in the run of properties between 150 and 152 Gilders Road there would be  large expanse of blank elevation visible in the streetscene. Coupled with the height of the elevation being exacerbated by the gable finish, it is considered that the proposed side flank would appear overly dominant in the streetscene and create an incongruous addition to the host porperty. It is considered that the proposed extensions as such would detract from the character and appearance of the surrounding area.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.It is considered that the proposed development would by virtue of its size, siting and design create an unecessary sense of enclosure at the rear to the neighbouring properties notably the donor site 150 Gilders Road and result in a loss of daylight/sunlight to the detriment of the neighbouring occupiers living conditions. Highways The proposed development would utilise an existing access road to the rear and off street parking would be provided in line with Policy T6.1 of the Lodon Plan for the existing and future unit proposed on the site. In addition a suitable level of cycle parking would be provided. Both off street parking and cycle parking could be secured by condition. The LPA's highways neighbourhood traffic engineer has reviewed the proposal and found it to be acceptable and raise no objection to the proposal.Whilst it is acknowledged that there may be 'but not proven' parking pressures as stated by the objector within the area it is considered that sufficient parking provision off street is provided for the proposed development and that in this instance there is not a necessity for any further mitgation measures to be imposed such as the requirement for occupants to sign and complete a legal agreement to preclude future occupants and their vistors applying and obtaining an on street parking permit should a future CPZ scheme come forward in the area. It is considered that the proposed development in itself would not increase demand for on street parking or lead to congestion or prejudice highway safety. Other mattersIt is noted that the applicants description of development omitted the fact that alterations and extensions and a sub division of the plot of the donor host property are proposed. However the LPA's assessment has taken these factors into consideration in making its assessment. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to not be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than not in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.
Condition 3 (Details of External Surfaces) - Officers have reviewed the information provided and are satisfied this can now be approved.
Condition 4 (Cycle Storage and Refuse and Recycling) - Officers have reviewed the information provided and are satisfied this can now be approved.

Please revise the householder validation check list with updated information. Please check the new local list in our website before filling the householder validation checklist.The new local validation list and checklists can be obtained via the council's website- https://www.kingston.gov.uk/downloads/download/261/validation-requirements-for-planning-applications.

The Householder Local List requires a completed Biodiversity Checklist for all householder applications. Please download a copy of the Biodiversity Checklist from: https://www.kingston.gov.uk/downloads/download/261/validation-requirements-for-planning-applications   It is at the bottom of the web page as a PDF. Please read the document and edit your answers.
Householder Checklist Incomplete - You have not provided a response for the provision of a "Construction Management Plan". Please complete this response.
Householder Checklist - please update this document with any changes you have made to your submission and re-submit it.
For the avoidance of doubt, please confirm the description 'Demolition of an existing side garage, porch and rear sun room, erection of a single storey side, front porch and rear extension.'

Please revise the validation check list with updated information if require.The new local validation list and checklists can be obtained via the council's website- https://www.kingston.gov.uk/downloads/download/261/validation-requirements-for-planning-applications.
Please provide 'Biodiversity Checklist.' The Biodiversity Checklists can be obtained via the council's website:https://www.kingston.gov.uk/downloads/file/2738/biodiversity-checklist
The use of the proposed site is HMO, therefore we require full planning application form and the submitted form is householder. Please find the attached application form.

Please provide a Proposed Block Plan as mentioned in the checklist drawn at an identified standard metric scale (such as 1:200 or 1:500) showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site. The Block Plan must show the direction of North and should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.
